intro: Lycoctonum sylvaticum, commonly known as the wild thimbleweed, is a flowering plant native to Europe and parts of Asia. It belongs to the Asteraceae family, which includes daisies and sunflowers, and is characterized by its composite flower heads. The plant typically grows in moist meadows and woodland edges, reaching heights of up to 60 centimeters. Its leaves are lance-shaped and covered in fine hairs, while the flowers are small and yellow, forming a cluster at the top of the stem. Lycoctonum sylvaticum is often found in disturbed soils and is considered a relatively common weed in certain regions.
